title: 106_hr583
content: The Act titled "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" treats Assistant United States Attorneys. The Act "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" includes Assistant United States Attorneys in the definition of law enforcement officers under the Civil Service Retirement System and Federal Employees' Retirement System. The Act "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" amends the Federal Employees' Retirement System to include Assistant United States Attorneys as law enforcement officers. The Act defines "Assistant United States Attorney" as an assistant appointed under section 542 of title 28. The Act and its amendments will take effect on the first day of the first applicable pay period after the 90-day period from enactment. SEC. 3. PROVISIONS RELATING TO INCUMBENTS. For the purposes of this section, an incumbent is defined as an individual appointed as an Assistant United States Attorney before the effective date of this Act. The Department of Justice must provide notice to these individuals regarding their election rights under this Act within 6 months of its effective date. Incumbents have the option to elect to be treated according to the amendments made by this Act or as if the Act had never been enacted. Failure to make a timely election will have consequences. Failure to make a timely election under this subsection will be treated as if an election was made on the last allowable day. The election must be made before the 90th day after the notice is provided or the incumbent separates from service. No changes in retirement coverage will occur until an election is made. The enactment of this Act will not affect any election made before the effective date. Incumbents who elect the option under subsection (c)(1)(A) will have their service as an Assistant United States Attorney treated according to the applicable provisions of title 5, United States Code. Makeup contributions are also addressed. Makeup contributions are required under subchapter III of chapter 83 or chapter 84 of title 5, United States Code. The Department of Justice must remit the specified amount to the Office of Personnel Management for deposit into the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund. The Department of Justice must remit the total amount of additional individual and Government contributions to the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund, plus interest, for all Assistant United States Attorneys before the effective date of their election under subsection (c). No individual liability is created for any shortfall in contributions required. The Office of Personnel Management will create regulations to implement the Act, including determining interest on contributions. The term "Assistant United States Attorney" refers to an assistant appointed under section 542 of title 28, United States Code.
